qas.question: What did the poles of the 17th century think the term szlachta came from?
What does schlachtan mean in german?
What German word is also suggestive deriving from  szlachta?
The polish believed szlachta derived from the name of who?

context: Poles of the 17th century assumed that "szlachta" came from the <a0_0>German "schlachten"<a0_0/> <a1_0>("to slaughter" or "to butcher")<a1_0/>; also suggestive is the German "<a2_0>Schlacht<a2_0/>" ("<a3_0>battle<a3_0/>"). Early Polish historians thought the term may have derived from the name of the <a4_0>legendary proto-Polish chief, Lech<a4_0/>, mentioned in Polish and Czech writings.
